newsitem.title: USA: Elections, economic data captivate U.S. markets.
newsitem.headline: Elections, economic data captivate U.S. markets.

text.p: For the next six weeks U.S. financial markets will fret over a possible leftward tilt in the next Congress and a slew of economic data that could clear up a muddy view on official interest rates, analysts said.

Congressional and presidential elections on November 5 will determine the fate of federal budget-balancing efforts and remove a big stumbling block for a Federal Reserve edging ever closer to raising short-term rates.
When Fed policy-makers next meet on November 13, they are unlikely to show as much patience as they did when they held rates steady at a meeting last Tuesday, the analysts said.

"Prior to the election, one needed very compelling numbers to give the Fed enough reason to raise rates. After the election, the numbers needn't be quite as compelling," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman at Goldman Sachs.

Economists disagree over how hesitant Fed officials were to raise rates so close to the elections, but none disputed that a return of Democratic control of the House of Representatives would dishearten investors hoping for an end federal deficits.

"The Democratic leadership is pretty liberal and balancing the budget is not one of their priorities. A Democratic House would probably rattle the markets quite a bit -- and the Fed," said Sung Wohn Sohn, chief economist at Norwest Corp.

Ahead of the election, and the November 13 Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, investors will glean what they can from crucial reports on September and October employment, third-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) growth, plus retail sales and inflation data for September.
The FOMC will have to make its decision without October retail sales and consumer price index data due November 14.
Stocks and bonds will likely sell off in anticipation of tighter monetary policy if the data fail to show a significant slowdown from the 4.7-percent growth in the second quarter, analysts said.
Third-quarter GDP growth above 3.0 percent, with continued job growth near 250,000 a month and rising wage pressures, would virtually guarantee a Fed rate hike, analysts said.

"Strong job gains and retail sales would tip the Fed toward moving. But numbers that show a healthy deceleration would be very bullish for the markets," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
Stocks could weather a Fed rate hike better than bonds, with signs of stronger economic growth offsetting fears of inflation and higher borrowing costs, analysts noted.
"My guess is after an initial correction because of higher rates, the equity market would be buoyed becaused of reduced concern about earnings," Hormats said.
Markets have led a charmed life in 1996. Even after months of talk of imminent Fed tightening, the Dow Jones industrial average is near its record high.
Meanwhile, the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond yield has hovered near 7.0 percent for nearly six months, staying between 6.75 and 7.25 percent.
Analysts believe that solid performance could continue if the Federal Reserve raised the federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, a quarter point to 5.5 percent.
"If the Fed moves in a reasonable fashion, to some extent that will remove some of the current (monetary policy) uncertainty. The market might go down, but it would recover quickly," said Cripps.
In the currency market, the dollar remains somewhat immune to Fed deliberations since the U.S. trade deficit has deteriorated, analysts said.
